title: Len Brennan
text:
Leonard Reginald 'Len' Brennan (1911-1943) was an Australian <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1930s. He was a casualty of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Career.
Len Brennan was a local from <a href="Ramsgate%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Ramsgate, New South Wales</a>, and played three seasons of first grade with the <a href="St%20George%20Dragons">St George Dragons</a> between 1932-1934, including the <a href="1933%20NSWRFL%20season">1933 Grand Final</a>. Len also played with his oldest brother <a href="Joe%20Brennan%20%28rugby%20league%29">Joe Brennan</a> at <a href="St.%20George">St. George</a> during his career. They were both wingers. 
War death.
Brennan enlisted in the <a href="RAAF">RAAF</a> during 1941 and became a <a href="Flight%20Sergeant">Flight Sergeant</a> in <a href="No.%20104%20Squadron%20RAF">104 Squadron</a>. On 8 June 1943, Brennan served as the co-pilot of a <a href="Vickers%20Wellington">Vickers Wellington</a> bomber sent on an operational flight. During the flight, the bomber was shot down, and all aboard save one were killed. An account of the day was written by the survivor, the pilot, <a href="Pilot%20Officer">Pilot Officer</a> F.E. McLaren.
McLaren was picked up by <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> ships at about 2:00 pm the next day, but nobody else survived.
